column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref

#Text=[0004] For existing three phase, 4-pole BLDC motors available in the marketplace, including outer rotor and inner rotor models, 6 slots is its most popular and simplest stator lamination structure in the low power applications.
#Text=FIG. 1 illustrates a prior art schematic winding diagram for a 3-phase BLDC motor.
#Text=The stator 12 has a stator core 13 with six stator poles 14, referred to as slots.
#Text=The rotor 16 has four magnetic poles 18 formed by four permanent magnets fixed to the outer surface of a rotor core 17 (in known manner).
#Text=The winding 20 forms a coil 22 about each stator pole 14.

#Text=The winding 20 is a 3-phase star winding, meaning that the winding 20 has three legs or phases, with one end (A,B,C) of each leg being connected to the stator terminals (one for each phase) and the other end (X,Y,Z) of each leg being connected together at point 24 to form a star connection.
#Text=Hence the motor is referred to as a three phase, four pole, six slot BLDC motor.
#Text=In this geometry there are six coils, two coils for each phase.
#Text=Thus each leg has two coils 22 electrically connected in series.
#Text=This is difficult to wind in small diameter motors.

#Text=[0005] The main problem with the existing stator geometry is that the winding configuration is complicated for small diameter, lower power applications, such as the automotive fuel pump, water pump and air pump, etc.
#Text=In these applications, the stator inner diameter is very small, just around 20 mm, therefore it is difficult to assemble more coils, especially for mass production.
#Text=[0006] Another problem with existing products is the high cogging torque, which creates noise and vibration.
#Text=This has restricted the use of BLDC motors in many fields which need low noise and low vibration.
#Text=In order to solve this problem, one of the most effective methods is the 4 pole, 9 slot configuration, as shown in FIG. 2.
#Text=From this figure we can see that the winding becomes even more complicated with three coils per phase and a lower efficiency caused by longer winding end-turns.
#Text=[0007] Another problem with existing products is that it is not suitable for overmold technology in the fuel pump application.
#Text=As diverse fuels will be used in the future, such as alcohol containing fuels, etc, to avoid oxidation of the magnetic wire, overmold is desired.
#Text=However, this results in the stator becoming a solid body, i.e., there is no space for fuel to pass through, except through the air gap between the rotor and the stator.
#Text=However, to maintain motor efficiency, the air gap is very small with the result that the fuel flow is insufficient.
#Text=[0008] Hence there is a desire for a brushless direct current (BLDC) motor which has a simple winding structure with low cogging torque.
